hough the transit nodes only make about 28% of the total nodes
nd their percentage is decreasing, their link birth rate is 29% higher
han that of stub links, and the death rate 74% higher. Note that the
ink birth and death counts lump together all the link changes that
an be either due to node birth/death or due to link adjustment be-
ween existing nodes. To quantify the latter, we define wiring as the
ddition of a new link between two existing nodes, and unwiring as
he removal of a link between two live nodes (i.e., the two inci-
ent nodes are still alive in the topology after the link is removed).
tub wirings and unwirings reflect customer’s actions of changing
roviders, while transit wirings and unwirings reflect provider’s ac-
ions of adjusting their inter-ISP connectivity.
Fig. 26 shows the net growth of wirings between July 24, 2004
nd May 25, 2006, a period that falls within our 90% confidence
argins. Here we consider only the nodes that are present through-
ut this measurement period and find 10349 such stub nodes and
319 transit nodes. We then count the wiring and unwiring events
mong these nodes. Fig. 26 shows that provider networks get more
ensely connected over time, perhaps as a result of serving ever
ncreasing customer demands10. Keeping in mind that the number
f transit nodes is much lower than the number of stub nodes, and
hat a transit wiring event means adding a link between two transit
odes only, we see a high net growth rate in transit links, despite
he high death rate shown in Fig. 23. This confirms a general obser-
ation that over recent years, provider networks have been actively
djusting their inter-connectivity.
What types of inter-ISP connectivity that providers are actively
djusting? Based on the type of inter-AS business relationships,
inks are generally classified into three classes: customer-to-provider
c2p), peer-to-peer (p2p), and sibling-to-sibling (e.g., ASes that be-
ong to the same company). Since the sibling relationship is rel-
tively rare, here we focus on c2p and p2p links only. In c2p re-
ationship, the customer (or lower-tier ISP) pays its provider (or
pper-tier ISP) to gain the global reachability. In p2p relationship,
ata traffic is exchanged free of charge between the two peers, but
nly traffic originated from a peer AS (or its customers) is allowed
n this link. We applied the PTE algorithm [18] to infer AS link
elationships, and the algorithm was able to infer the relationships
or 75% of all the links involved in wirings and unwirings. We clas-
